text:
The door to the bar was locked. Svidrigaïlov felt at home in this room and might spend whole days there. The tavern was dirty and not even decent.

"I was going to see you and looking for you," Raskolnikov said. "But I don't know why I turned from the Hay Market to X. Prospect just now. I never take this path. I usually turn right from the Hay Market. This isn't the way to you. I just turned, and here you are. It's strange!"

"Why don't you just say 'it's a miracle'?" Svidrigaïlov asked.

"Because it might just be coincidence."

"Oh, that's how you all are," Svidrigaïlov laughed. "You won't admit it, even if you secretly think it's a miracle! You say it might just be chance. And people here are too scared to have their own opinions, you can't imagine, Rodion Romanovitch. I don't mean you; you have your own opinion and aren't afraid to share it. That's what made me curious about you."

"Is that all?" Raskolnikov asked.

"Well, that's enough," Svidrigaïlov replied, clearly feeling a bit cheerful, but he had only had half a glass of wine.

"I think you came to see me before you knew I could have my own opinion," Raskolnikov said.

"Oh, well, it was a different situation. Everyone has their own plans. And speaking of miracles, let me tell you..."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov unexpectedly encounters Svidrigaïlov at a dismal tavern, leading to a discussion about chance and belief in miracles.
